bioghist.p: John Boit was born in Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts in 1858. He was a graduate of Harvard Law School. He studied architecture in New York for several years and built the New York Yacht Clubhouse in Newport. Thereafter he studied painting under John LaFarge, and again in Julien's Studio in Paris. In 1904 he married Louise Horstmann (b. 1869) of Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscript letters and other documents given to the Athenaeum by Mr. and Mrs. Peyton Biddle. A number of the manuscripts relate to John Boit and his wife Louise Horstmann Boit. Materials include letters to Louise Boit, including a series of letters from Edith Hamilton, 1945-1957, and correspondence between Aubrey Stanhope and Louise Horstmann. One letter from Stanhope, dated 1896, describes the "social side of the Coronation" of the Empress of Russia, with discussion of Europeans and Americans present for the occasion). John Boit's correspondence includes a letter to Stephen Leacock from John Boit, undated, and a letter to John Boit from Chief Justice Edward Douglass White, 1910. Other correspondence in the collection includes: a letter from Josiah Quincy, Jr. (1744-1775) to his father, 1773-1774; a letter from Josiah Quincy III (1772-1864) to Frederick Packard, 1859-1860; a letter from James Madison to James Ogilvie, 1809; a 1770 summons signed by Edward Shippen; an 1863 letter to Secretary of War Stanton from Thaddeus Stevens; a letter from Horace Greeley to William D. Kelley related to the movement of troops into Richmond in 1862; and several Civil War era passes for W. D. Kelley. The collection also includes one folder of typed transcripts of letters of the King family, 1812-1826. The letters between family members in Jamaica and in the United States discuss health and activities of family and friends, and several letters make reference to the family's slaves. The original King family letters are held by the York County Historical Society.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
